body_html: @soumith, if there are no launch bounds, it is in fact possible that a kernel is compiled to request more registers than available. At the compile time, compiler does not know how many threads you'll want to launch with, so, potentially, it can use too many registers per thread to later satisfy runtime requirements, and, e.g. trying to launch with 512 or 1024 threads could fail (not even a single block can be put on an SM), whereas launching with 256 would succeed.
body_text: @soumith, if there are no launch bounds, it is in fact possible that a kernel is compiled to request more registers than available. At the compile time, compiler does not know how many threads you'll want to launch with, so, potentially, it can use too many registers per thread to later satisfy runtime requirements, and, e.g. trying to launch with 512 or 1024 threads could fail (not even a single block can be put on an SM), whereas launching with 256 would succeed.
body: @soumith, if there are no launch bounds, it is in fact possible that a kernel is compiled to request more registers than available. At the compile time, compiler does not know how many threads you'll want to launch with, so, potentially, it can use too many registers per thread to later satisfy runtime requirements, and, e.g. trying to launch with 512 or 1024 threads could fail (not even a single block can be put on an SM), whereas launching with 256 would succeed.
